009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
015
016import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
017import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
018import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.EigenDecompositionJama;
019
020/**
021 * <p>
022 * Algebraic ellipse fit using Fitzgibbon's original method [1], based on simple
023 * matrix inversion. See [2, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed description.
024 * Note: This implementation does not use data centering nor accepts a specific
025 * reference point. With exactly 5 input points (generally sufficient for
026 * ellipse fitting) the scatter matrix X is singular and in this case matrix S
027 * has no inverse. Thus at least 6 distinct input points are required (i.e., no
028 * duplicate points are allowed).
029 * </p>
030 * <p>
031 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least- squares
032 * fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine
033 * Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999).<br>
034 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
035 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
036 * </p>
037 * 
038 * @author WB
039 * @version 2022/11/17
040 */
041public class EllipseFitFitzgibbonNaive implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
042        
043        // constraint matrix
044        private static final RealMatrix C = Matrix.makeRealMatrix(6, 6,
045                                0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0,
046                                0,-1, 0, 0, 0, 0,
047                                2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
048                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
049                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
050                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 );
051        
052        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) ellipse parameters
053        
054        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonNaive(Pnt2d[] points) {
055                if (points.length < 6) {
056                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("fitter requires at least 6 sample points instead of " + points.length);
057                }
058                this.q = fit(points);
059        }
060
061        @Override
062        public double[] getParameters() {
063                return this.q;
064        }
065        
066        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points) {
067                final int n = points.length;
068
069                // create design matrix X:
070                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 6);
071                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
072                        double x = points[i].getX();
073                        double y = points[i].getY();
074                        X.setEntry(i, 0, sqr(x));
075                        X.setEntry(i, 1, x * y);
076                        X.setEntry(i, 2, sqr(y));
077                        X.setEntry(i, 3, x);
078                        X.setEntry(i, 4, y);
079                        X.setEntry(i, 5, 1);
080                }
081                
082                // scatter matrix S:
083                RealMatrix S = X.transpose().multiply(X);       
084                RealMatrix Si = MatrixUtils.inverse(S, 1e-15);
085                
086//              EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(Si.multiply(C));
087                EigenDecompositionJama ed = new EigenDecompositionJama(Si.multiply(C));
088
089                double[] evals = ed.getRealEigenvalues();
090                int k = Matrix.idxMax(evals);                           // index of the largest eigenvalue
091                return ed.getEigenvector(k).toArray();
092        }
093        
094}
